[Report de-identified (Safe-harbor compliant) by De-ID v.6.22.07.0]
CONSULTING PHYSICIAN: **NAME[YYY ZZZ], D.O.
REASON FOR CONSULTATION: Rehabilitation evaluation following a fall and an old bilateral lacunar infarct with ataxia.
HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS: This is an **AGE[in 80s]-year-old female, with past medical history significant for Alzheimer's dementia, hypertension, left internal carotid artery stenosis, coronary artery disease, degenerative joint disease, diabetes mellitus type 2, gastroesophageal reflux disease, and hiatal hernia, who was admitted on **DATE[Apr 16 07] after a fall at home. Family reports the patient did not strike her head and there apparently was no loss of consciousness. A head CT upon admission to the Emergency Department revealed atrophy and chronic small vessel ischemic changes, as well as small, old, lacunar infarcts in both basal ganglia, as well as some sinus disease and mastoiditis. A left foot x-ray was performed and revealed degenerative changes. A left ankle x-ray was also performed and was negative for fracture. A right shoulder fracture did reveal an impacted surgical neck fracture, as well as degenerative joint disease of the acromioclavicular joint. Pelvic x-rays were performed and were found to be negative for fracture.
The patient was evaluated by Dr. **NAME[SSS] from Orthopedics. Apparently the right humeral fracture is an old fracture and he recommended conservative measures and cleared the patient for weightbearing as tolerated. She is also cleared for passive range-of-motion and active range-of-motion of the right shoulder. The patient was also evaluated by Dr. **NAME[RRR] from ENT who did not feel that she has an acute case of mastoiditis. He recommended cerumen removal as an outpatient.
Apparently the patient had been living with family members. Her history is obtained from the chart. She is suffering from Alzheimer's dementia and is unable to relay any history for me today. She does complain of some left ankle pain at this time, but otherwise has no other complaints. She does move all 4 extremities and does follow some simple commands.
ALLERGIES: AN ANTIBIOTIC.
CURRENT MEDICATIONS: Glyburide, Protonix, Synthroid, moexipril, triamterene hydrochlorothiazide, donepezil, Theragran, and Namenda.
PAST MEDICAL HISTORY: Alzheimer's dementia, history of hypertension, old left frontal infarct, left internal carotid artery stenosis 30%, coronary artery disease, degenerative joint disease, chronic maxillary sinusitis, diabetes mellitus type 2, gastroesophageal reflux disease, large hiatal hernia, mild mitral regurgitation and tricuspid regurgitation and aortic regurgitation.
PAST SURGICAL HISTORY: Total abdominal hysterectomy in 1990 and bladder repair in 1992.
FAMILY HISTORY: The patient's mother died at age **AGE[in 80s]. Father also died at age **AGE[in 80s]. The patient's sister has arthritis. She does have one brother who is alive at the age of **AGE[in 70s].
SOCIAL HISTORY: She does not smoke or drink alcohol. She apparently lives with family members in a 1-story home with an unknown number of steps.
PAST LEVEL OF FUNCTIONING: Apparently the patient was able to ambulate fairly independently. I do not known if she used an assistive device.
CURRENT LEVEL OF FUNCTIONING: Yesterday with Physical Therapy the patient was able to ambulate 360 feet with a rolling walker and supervision. She transferred supine to sit and sit to supine with independence. She transferred sit to stand with contact guard assistance.
REVIEW OF SYSTEMS: This is somewhat difficult to obtain as the patient is demented. She does complain of pain at the left ankle at this time. She is very hard of hearing.
PHYSICAL EXAMINATION: GENERAL: This is a pleasant **AGE[in 80s]-year-old female who is awake, alert, hard of hearing, but in no acute distress. She is pleasantly confused.
VITAL SIGNS: Temperature is 98, pulse 61, respirations 18, blood pressure 98/48.
HEENT: Head is normocephalic, atraumatic. Pupils are round and reactive to light and accommodation. Extraocular muscles are intact.
HEART: Regular rate and rhythm.
LUNGS: Clear to auscultation bilaterally.
ABDOMEN: Soft, nontender, nondistended, and bowel sounds are present.
EXTREMITIES: There is very mild erythema over the medial aspect of the left ankle but otherwise there is no edema and no calf tenderness present. She does have very limited active range-of-motion at the right shoulder because of pain.
NEUROLOGIC: Cranial nerves II-XII appear to be grossly intact. Sensation to light touch is intact in all 4 extremities. She does move all 4 extremities spontaneously and follows some simple commands. Plantar reflexes were down-going bilaterally. Muscle stretch reflexes were 1 over 4 at biceps, triceps and patella and Achilles throughout. Motor strength for grip bilaterally was 4+. Dorsiflexion and plantar flexion were also 4+/5 bilaterally.
IMPRESSION: This is an **AGE[in 80s]-year-old female who is status post a fall at home. She suffers from ataxia and has a history of old bilateral lacunar infarcts and an old right humeral fracture and a left ankle sprain. She is currently cleared for weightbearing as tolerated and is okay for passive and active range-of-motion at the right shoulder. She has been doing quite well with physical therapy actually and walked 360 feet yesterday with a walker and supervision. At this point, she may not qualify for skilled PT and OT based on her current level of function. She probably would benefit from further physical therapy and occupational therapy, perhaps as an outpatient or with Home Care Services following her. She would benefit from these services to improve her balance, transfers and ambulation. I will continue to follow this patient with you.
Thank you very kindly for allowing me to participate in the care of this patient.
